summary.title: Hogwarts Quidditch Festival App Threat Model
summary.description: This threat model covers the mobile app for the Hogwarts Quidditch Olympic Festival, used for fan engagement, scheduling, ticket purchasing, event check-in, VIP access, community features, vendor information, and sponsor advertising. It includes connections to third-parties like payment systems, security agencies, and external data providers, with a focus on ensuring compliance with Magic & Mystics Regulations (MMRs) for data privacy and security.

diagrams.title: Hogwarts Quidditch Festival App Threat Model

threats.title: Leaked User Profiles
threats.description: Attackers may access or leak user profile data in the Community Aspect, exposing sensitive information and violating MMRs.
threats.mitigation: Encrypt communications with HTTPS, enforce strict access controls, and allow users to delete data via a ‘Right to Delete’ feature per MMRs.

threats.title: Unauthorized Ticket Purchases
threats.description: Attackers may spoof user identities to purchase tickets without authorization, risking financial loss and MMR violations.
threats.mitigation: Use MFA, secure login, and transaction signing to verify user identity and prevent unauthorized purchases. Encrypt payment data in transit.

threats.title: New STRIDE threat
threats.description: Provide a description for this threat
threats.mitigation: Provide remediation for this threat or a reason if status is N/A

threats.title: Altered Schedule Data
threats.description: Attackers may alter live schedule data in the app, disrupting event planning and attendee experience, potentially violating MMRs.
threats.mitigation: Use integrity checks (e.g., hashes), encrypt data in transit, and restrict access to authorized personnel only.

threats.title: Unauthorized Event Access
threats.description: Attackers may gain unauthorized access to events by elevating privileges during check-in, bypassing security and violating MMRs.
threats.mitigation: Use secure authentication (e.g., magical tokens, MFA), verify check-ins with Security Agencies in real-time, and restrict access with role checks.

threats.title: Denial of Check-In Service
threats.description: Attackers may launch a denial-of-service attack, preventing attendees from checking in and disrupting festival operations.
threats.mitigation: Use load balancing, redundancy, and DDoS protection to ensure check-in availability.

threats.title: Unauthorized VIP Access
threats.description: Attackers may gain unauthorized VIP access, allowing premium features without payment and violating MMRs.
threats.mitigation: Restrict access with strong authentication, role checks, and physical/magical tokens. Encrypt VIP data and monitor access logs.

threats.title: Tampered Vendor Data
threats.description: Attackers may tamper with vendor data in storage, affecting festival operations and sponsor trust.
threats.mitigation: Use digital signatures, audit logs for changes, and encrypt data at rest to prevent tampering.

threats.title: Unavailability of Ads
threats.description: Attackers may launch a denial-of-service attack, making sponsor ads unavailable and disrupting revenue streams.
threats.mitigation: Use load balancing, redundancy, and DDoS protection services to ensure ad availability.

threats.title: Malicious Ad Injection
threats.description: Attackers may inject malicious ads into Sponsor Advertising, compromising attendee devices or spreading malware, violating MMRs.
threats.mitigation: Validate ad content before display, use secure ad servers, and monitor ad traffic for anomalies.

threats.title: Database Breach
threats.description: Attackers may breach the Database, exposing attendee, ticket, and event data, violating MMRs and risking privacy.
threats.mitigation: Encrypt data at rest and in transit, use role-based access control (RBAC), and conduct regular security audits.

threats.title: Repudiation of Data Access
threats.description: Attendees or attackers may deny accessing or modifying data in the Database, complicating accountability and MMR compliance.
threats.mitigation: Log all data access and changes with timestamps and user IDs, and use digital signatures to ensure non-repudiation.

threats.title: “Payment Data Exposure” (Information Disclosure)
threats.description: Third-party Payment System may leak sensitive payment data, exposing attendee financial information and violating MMRs.
threats.mitigation: Use PCI-compliant processors, tokenize data, and enforce end-to-end encryption (HTTPS) for all payment transactions.

threats.title: Intercepted Payment Data
threats.description: Attackers may intercept payment data during transmission between Payment System and Ticket Purchasing, risking data breaches and violating Magic & Mystics Regulations (MMRs). This involves eavesdropping on network traffic or exploiting unsecured APIs.
threats.mitigation: Encrypt data in transit with HTTPS, use secure APIs, and implement intrusion detection systems to detect and prevent interception.

threats.title: Tampered Check-In Verification
threats.description: Attackers may tamper with check-in verification data between Security Agencies and Event Check-In, allowing unauthorized access or false attendance records.
threats.mitigation: Use integrity checks (e.g., digital signatures), encrypt data in transit, and monitor data flows for anomalies.

threats.title: Intercepted Event Data
threats.description: Attackers may intercept event details during transmission from External Data Providers to Live Schedule, risking data breaches and MMR violations.
threats.mitigation: Encrypt data in transit with HTTPS, use secure APIs, and implement intrusion detection systems to prevent interception.

threats.title: Intercepted Vendor Data
threats.description: Attackers may intercept vendor data during transmission from External Data Providers to Vendor Information, risking data breaches and MMR violations.
threats.mitigation: Encrypt data in transit with HTTPS, use secure APIs, and implement intrusion detection systems to prevent interception.

threats.title: Impersonation of Payment System
threats.description: Attackers may impersonate the third-party Payment System to gain unauthorized access, potentially exposing attendee payment data and violating Magic & Mystics Regulations (MMRs). This could involve spoofing API calls or credentials to extract sensitive financial information.
threats.mitigation: Authenticate Payment System interactions with strong API keys, use HTTPS for all communications, and enforce strict access controls to prevent impersonation. Regular audits of API usage can detect spoofing attempts.

threats.title: Fake Check-Ins
threats.description: Attackers may spoof check-in data or impersonate Security Agencies to allow unauthorized event access, violating MMRs and risking security breaches.
threats.mitigation: Use secure authentication (e.g., magical tokens, MFA), real-time validation, and logs for check-in data to prevent spoofing.

threats.title: Impersonation of Data Provider
threats.description: Attackers may impersonate External Data Providers by spoofing API calls to alter event, team, or vendor data, disrupting festival operations and violating MMRs.
threats.mitigation: Authenticate API calls with strong keys, use HTTPS for data exchange, and monitor API usage for anomalies to prevent impersonation.

threats.title: Impersonation of Users
threats.description: Attackers may impersonate legitimate attendees by spoofing user credentials or sessions in the Hogwarts Quidditch Festival mobile app (Browser/App). This could allow unauthorized access to user accounts, ticket purchases, or community features, violating Magic & Mystics Regulations (MMRs) and risking attendee data exposure.
threats.mitigation: Implement multi-factor authentication (MFA) using magical tokens or biometric verification, enforce secure login with strong password policies and HTTPS, and monitor login attempts with real-time alerts to detect and prevent impersonation attempts. Regularly audit authentication logs for compliance with Magic & Mystics Regulations (MMRs).
